key_points: There are three types of markers installed as part of an Instrument Landing System (ILS), and they can be used for any instrument approach
The marker in question is the Outer Marker (OM), which is at the point on the approach that the aircraft would be around 1500 ft
Outer marker: (OM) This marker normally indicates the Final Approach Fix (FAF)
learning.explanation: There are three types of markers installed as part of an Instrument Landing System (ILS), and they can be used for any instrument approach. The marker in question is the Outer Marker (OM), which is at the point on the approach that the aircraft would be around 1500 ft. Outer marker: (OM) This marker normally indicates the Final Approach Fix (FAF). It is located between 4 and 7 nm from the runway threshold on the same course as the localiser. When passing the outer marker, the pilot receives an audio tone in a continuous series at 400 Hz, accompanied by a flashing blue light in a series of dashes (2 per second). "- - - - - - " Middle marker: (MM) This marker normally indicates the CAT I Missed approach point and it is positioned between 0.5 and 0.8 nm from the runway threshold. When passing the middle marker, the pilot receives an audio tone in a continuous series at 1300 Hz, accompanied by a flashing amber light in a sequence of alternating dots and dashes. "-. -. -. -." Inner marker: (IM) This marker normally indicates the passing of the runway threshold. When passing the inner marker, the pilot receives an audio tone in a continuous series of 3000 Hz, accompanied by a flashing white light in a sequence of dots (6 per second). "."

content.question: A pilot has selected the appropriate ILS frequency for the approach that they are currently established on. Which of the following scenarios would cause a warning flag to appear on both the Localiser (LOC) and GIide Path (GP) indications?

options.A: Absence of both carrier waves.
options.B: A difference in depth of modulation of zero.
options.C: Excessive LOC and GP deviations.
options.D: Loss of ILS ident transmission.

key_points: Learning Objective 062
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 062.02.05.02.05: Describe the circumstances in which warning flags will appear for both the LOC and the GP: absence of the carrier frequency; absence of the modulation simultaneously; the percentage modulation of the navigation signal reduced to 0. When on the approach, the sudden appearanc of both flags must mean a fault of some kind (not just being out of range), so this must be down to one of the faults listed in the learning objective above. The easiest fault to remember is correct in this case, as the sudden absence of a carrier wave is certainly going to remove LOC and GP indications and will therefore show warning flags. The other answers are wrong because: The difference in depth of modulation (DDM) is the way an ILS tells you where you are in relation to the localiser centreline or the glide path, and a DDM of zero means being exactly on the LOC or GP. "Excessive LOC or GP deviations" is vague, but even when at more than full scale deflection (but within the coverage area), the indicators still show the direction we are off track/glidepath. Loss of ident transmission would not show flags on its own, but there might be a common error which causes both flags to show and the ident to stop transmitting, such as a total power loss, etc.

content.question: You are performing an NDB approach on RWY 23. Given a magnetic Track of 230º, Magnetic HDG of 240º, and a QDM 236. Are you established?

options.A: No, because the Magnetic Heading is not within 5º of the required NDB bearing.
options.B: Yes, because the Magnetic Heading is within 10º of the required NDB bearing.
options.C: No, because the QDM is more than 5º apart from the required bearing.
options.D: Yes, because the QDM is within 10º of from the required bearing.

key_points: A Non-Directional Beacon (NDB) is a ground-based, low frequency radio transmitter used as an instrument approach for airports and offshore platforms
The NDB transmits an omni-directional signal that is received by the ADF or Automatic Direction Finder, a standard instrument onboard aircraft
The pilot uses the ADF to determine the direction to the NDB relative to the aircraft
learning.explanation: A Non-Directional Beacon (NDB) is a ground-based, low frequency radio transmitter used as an instrument approach for airports and offshore platforms. The NDB transmits an omni-directional signal that is received by the ADF or Automatic Direction Finder, a standard instrument onboard aircraft. The pilot uses the ADF to determine the direction to the NDB relative to the aircraft. NDB's can be used to provide a non-precision approach to an airport. A pilot can make sure to be aligned with the correct approach path by maintaining the same QDM with the ADF, and can manage vertical guidance using their altimeter, with a minimum descent height/altitude. In terms of lateral errors permitted, flying an NDB approach, you must maintain a QDM/QDR that is ± 5° of the designated approach path. This is also the range in which an aircraft can be considered "established" on the approach. ICAO Doc 8 168 - Aircraft Operations The aircraft shall cross the fix or facility and fly outbound on the specified track, descending as necessary to the procedure altitude/height but no lower than the minimum crossing altitude/height associated with that segment. If a further descent is specified after the inbound turn, this descent shall not be started until the aircraft is established on the inbound track. An aircraft is considered established when it is: A) within half full scale deflection for the ILS and VOR; or B) within ±5° of the required bearing for the NDB.

content.question: The function of the BFO (Beat Frequency Oscillator) is

options.A: to make the modulating tone audible in order to identify N0N/A1A modulated NDBs.
options.B: to make the carrier wave audible in order to identify N0N/A1A modulated NDBs.
options.C: to make the modulating tone audible in order to identify A2A modulated NDBs.
options.D: to make the carrier wave audible in order to identify A2A modulated NDBs.

key_points: N0N of the emission is the transmission of an unmodulated carrier wave, which would not be detectable on a normal receiver
That’s why a so called Beat Frequency Oscillator (BFO) is used
The Beat Frequency Oscillator (BFO) produces an offset frequency within the receiver which when combined with the received frequency produces a tone of 400-1020 Hz
learning.explanation: N0N of the emission is the transmission of an unmodulated carrier wave, which would not be detectable on a normal receiver. That’s why a so called Beat Frequency Oscillator (BFO) is used. The Beat Frequency Oscillator (BFO) produces an offset frequency within the receiver which when combined with the received frequency produces a tone of 400-1020 Hz. A1A is the emission of an interrupted unmodulated carrier wave which requires the BFO to be on for aural reception.

content.question: An aircraft is on radial 120 with a magnetic heading of 300°, the track selector (OBS) reads 330. The indications on the Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) are to fly:

options.A: right with FROM showing.
options.B: left with FROM showing.
options.C: right with TO showing.
options.D: left with TO showing.

key_points: Start by drawing the VOR and the known radials from it, in this case, we can draw our aircraft somewhere along the 120º radial, and also we can draw the radials for our chosen OBS course
Those would be the 330º radial (330 FROM) and the opposite direction, the 150º radial (330 TO)
We then can see the same as in the figure above
learning.explanation: Start by drawing the VOR and the known radials from it, in this case, we can draw our aircraft somewhere along the 120º radial, and also we can draw the radials for our chosen OBS course. Those would be the 330º radial (330 FROM) and the opposite direction, the 150º radial (330 TO). We then can see the same as in the figure above. The heading does not matter here, as we are using a CDI (course deviation indicator), which has no heading input at all. If you need to imagine a heading, imagine that you are heading whatever the OBS course is set to, as that is how to find the most intuitive use of the CDI. We must work out which of the course lines we are closest to, and it is obvious that we are closer to the 150º radial, which we have called 330 TO. This means that the "TO" indication will be showing on our CDI. Now the CDI thinks we want to fly the 330 TO track towards the VOR, so at the moment we are right of track, therefore, the CDI will show a "fly left" indication. As we are more than 10º off the track radial, then the CDI will show full deflection "fly left".

content.question: An aircraft is flying over water towards a VOR/DME station. When the pilots are approaching the station, the warning flag on their CDI pops up. What is the reason for that?

options.A: The receiver in your aircraft senses that the values are wrong, that is why it shows an error flag.
options.B: The ground station measures that the indications exceed certain limits and shuts them down.
options.C: Skywaves and ground waves interfere and cancel themselves.
options.D: The wrong VOR frequency has been tuned in.

learning.explanation: 062.02.03.01.09: State that failure of the VOR station to stay within the required limits can cause the removal of identification and navigation components from the carrier or radiation to cease. When the warning flag on a VOR/DME CDI (Course Deviation Indicator) pops up, it indicates that the ground station has detected a problem with the signals being received by the aircraft. The VOR/DME ground station continuously monitors the signals it is transmitting, and if it detects that the signals are being received out of tolerance, it sends a flag to the aircraft warning the pilots that the signals may be unreliable. "The receiver in your aircraft senses that the values are wrong, that is why it shows an error flag." is incorrect because the receiver in the aircraft is not responsible for displaying the warning flag. It is simply receiving and displaying the signals it is receiving from the ground station. VOR automatic self-monitoring system The monitoring system gives a warning if there is the following: Change in bearing in excess of 1º. Reduction of more than 15% in the signal strength of the carrier or modulated components. Failure of the monitor itself. Should any of the above cases occur, the identification and the navigation signals may be removed or the VOR signal radiation may cease. In this case, the onboard equipment will show a warning flag

content.question: An aircraft is flying at FL 240. The DME-reading, uncorrected for altitude, is 8 NM. What is the ground distance to the beacon?

options.A: 7.3 NM
options.B: 6.5 NM
options.C: 7.5 NM
options.D: 7.0 NM

key_points: Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) is a navigation beacon that can indicate the aircraft’s position relative to the beacon
Aircraft send out a signal which is sent back by the DME ground equipment
Based on the delay of receiving the signal back, the aircraft can calculate the relative distance to the DME ground equipment
learning.explanation: Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) is a navigation beacon that can indicate the aircraft’s position relative to the beacon. Aircraft send out a signal which is sent back by the DME ground equipment. Based on the delay of receiving the signal back, the aircraft can calculate the relative distance to the DME ground equipment. As seen in the figure, the aircraft is at an altitude of 24.000 feet. (FL240). The slant range from the aircraft to the DME is 8 NM. By calculating the ground distance from the aircraft to the DME station, convert the following: 24.000 feet into nautical miles. Use the following table: 1 NM 6080 ft. ? 24.000 ft. ? = (24.000 ft x1 nm)/(6080 ft) = 3,95 nm Using the ABC-formulae the following can be calculated: A² + B² = C² Knowing that: A = 3,95 nm B = ? C = 8 nm Rewriting the formulae gives the following: B² = C² - A² B² = (8)² - (3,95)² B² = 48,4 B = √48,4 = 6,95 nm = 7 nm.

content.question: The reading of the RMI bearing is 300° at the tip of the needle. The magnetic variation at the DR position is 24°W, the magnetic variation at the NDB is 22°W and the deviation is -2°. The compass heading is 020°. The true bearing is:

key_points: In this case, we assume that the RMI is subjected to electromagnetic interference and therefore, deviation is applied: -2ºW (westerly deviation) Let’s start by converting compass heading to magnetic heading: Deviation west, compass best; Deviation east, compass least
20º - 2º = 18ºM Since the question asks for true bearing, we need to correct for magnetic variation: Variation west, magnetic best; Variation east, magnetic least

Remember that for NDB/ADF bearings the bearings are taken at the aircraft, therefore the magnetic variation applicable at the aircraft's position is to be used: 24ºW => therefore, we need to subtract it from the Magnetic bearing: 18º - 24º = 354º The RMI heading: 020ºC Bearing to the beacon: 300º Relative bearing = 300º - 20º = 280º Bearing to (QUJ) = Heading + Relative Bearing Bearing to (QUJ) = 354º + 280º = 634º Bearing to (QUJ) = 634º - 360º = 274ºT
learning.explanation: In this case, we assume that the RMI is subjected to electromagnetic interference and therefore, deviation is applied: -2ºW (westerly deviation) Let’s start by converting compass heading to magnetic heading: Deviation west, compass best; Deviation east, compass least. 20º - 2º = 18ºM Since the question asks for true bearing, we need to correct for magnetic variation: Variation west, magnetic best; Variation east, magnetic least. Remember that for NDB/ADF bearings the bearings are taken at the aircraft, therefore the magnetic variation applicable at the aircraft's position is to be used: 24ºW => therefore, we need to subtract it from the Magnetic bearing: 18º - 24º = 354º The RMI heading: 020ºC Bearing to the beacon: 300º Relative bearing = 300º - 20º = 280º Bearing to (QUJ) = Heading + Relative Bearing Bearing to (QUJ) = 354º + 280º = 634º Bearing to (QUJ) = 634º - 360º = 274ºT

content.question: In a modern FMS-equipped aircraft with a modern ADF receiver, the Beat Frequency Oscillator:

options.A: Is not installed because NON/A1A NDB stations are no longer in use.
options.B: Must be activated by hand
options.C: May be activated either automatically or by hand
options.D: Is activated automatically

key_points: Navigational NDBs have an unmodulated carrier wave (ICAO classification N0N)
Station identification is transmitted at roughly ten second intervals
Older systems interrupt the carrier wave (Keying) to send an unmodulated (but also inaudible) morse code ident (classified as A1A)
learning.explanation: Navigational NDBs have an unmodulated carrier wave (ICAO classification N0N). Station identification is transmitted at roughly ten second intervals. Older systems interrupt the carrier wave (Keying) to send an unmodulated (but also inaudible) morse code ident (classified as A1A). User will have also erratic indications while the signal is interrupted in this type of beacon. To make the unmodulated parts of the A1A signal audible, ADF equipment incorporates a Beat Frequency Oscillator (BF0) that produces a signal slightly removed from the received frequency that is then mixed with it. The mixing of the two frequencies produces an audible beat frequency, tahat is the difference of the two. In aircraft whit old ADF receivers the BFO mode is activated and annunciated when the “BFO” button is depressed, and permits the carrier wave and the associated Morse code identifier broadcast on the carrier wave to be heard. In modern FMS equipped aircraft whit modern ADF receiver, the BFO is automatically activated. Summary: selecting the BFO on makes the N0N carrier wave audible and allows the A1A type of ident to be heard. Note: BFO is not needed for an A2A signal which is already modulated to an audible frequency.

content.question: A radio beacon has an operational range of 10 NM. By what factor should the transmitter power be increased in order to achieve an operational range of 20 NM?

options.A: Four
options.B: Six
options.C: Eight
options.D: Two

key_points: The range of a NDB beacon is controlled primarily by its power: The formulas (for approximate answers) to determine range are: Max range over water (NM) = 3 x Square root of Power (Watts) Max range over land (NM) = 2 x Square root of Power (Watts) Therefore for the Range to be double, the Trasmitting Power must be quadrupled! Note 1: The formula does not include the effect of ground conductivity or frequency
Note 2: To double the range requires four times the power
learning.explanation: The range of a NDB beacon is controlled primarily by its power: The formulas (for approximate answers) to determine range are: Max range over water (NM) = 3 x Square root of Power (Watts) Max range over land (NM) = 2 x Square root of Power (Watts) Therefore for the Range to be double, the Trasmitting Power must be quadrupled! Note 1: The formula does not include the effect of ground conductivity or frequency. Note 2: To double the range requires four times the power.

content.question: What is the function of a marker beacon on an ILS approach?

options.A: It is used to indicate a requirement to commence the final approach procedure.
options.B: It is to indicate aircraft's vertical position in relation to the glide path.
options.C: It is used to indicate a requirement to initiate a configuration change.
options.D: It indicates aircraft's horizontal position during the approach.

key_points: Marker beacons are placed in a predetermined sequence before the threshold
The task of the markers is to produce a radiation pattern with a vertical beam upwards
By locating the markers at set distances before the threshold, the pilot can expect to fly above the markers at known distances
learning.explanation: Marker beacons are placed in a predetermined sequence before the threshold. The task of the markers is to produce a radiation pattern with a vertical beam upwards. By locating the markers at set distances before the threshold, the pilot can expect to fly above the markers at known distances. Consequently, the remaining distance from the final approach can be monitored. Therefore, we can say that the marker beacons indicate the aircraft’s horizontal position during the approach.

content.question: The transmission of the glide slope beacon is characterised by a:

options.A: VHF frequency modulated with a 90 Hz AM and 150 Hz AM navigation signal.
options.B: UHF frequency with a minimum range of 10 NM.
options.C: 300 to 3000 Hz Amplitude modulation for the ATIS.
options.D: UHF carrier frequency with a possible ‘voice ident’.

key_points: LOCALISER AND GLIDE PATH Frequency range: The localiser transmits in the VHF frequency range with horizontally-polarised transmissions
The glide path transmission signal is also horizontally-polarised but operated in the UHF frequency band
By using the UHF frequency band compared to the VHF localiser, interferences are avoided
learning.explanation: LOCALISER AND GLIDE PATH Frequency range: The localiser transmits in the VHF frequency range with horizontally-polarised transmissions. The glide path transmission signal is also horizontally-polarised but operated in the UHF frequency band. By using the UHF frequency band compared to the VHF localiser, interferences are avoided. Coverage: Localiser coverage is ensured: Over a 25 NM radius arc with +/- 10º angular width from the approach track; and further Over a 17 NM radius arc with +/- 35º angular width from the approach track. Glide Path: The azimuth coverage is a 10 NM radius arc with an angular width of +(- 8º from the runway centreline.

content.question: At night, the ionosphere undergoes changes in ionisation density, leading to fluctuations in the strength of received signals in the LF/MF frequency band. This phenomenon is commonly referred to as...

options.A: fading, caused by the received ground wave and sky wave going out of phase.
options.B: absorption mostly affects the ground wave and is dependent on the transmission power.
options.C: fading, caused by the received ground wave and sky wave going in phase.
options.D: attenuation and its impact are greatest on sky waves with high transmitted frequencies.

key_points: Night Effect The principal propagation method of NDBs is the ground wave
However it is possible for weak sky waves to be returned at night when the ionosphere is less dense and attenuation is least
During the day, the D-layer of the ionosphere absorbs signals in the LF and MF bands
learning.explanation: Night Effect The principal propagation method of NDBs is the ground wave. However it is possible for weak sky waves to be returned at night when the ionosphere is less dense and attenuation is least. During the day, the D-layer of the ionosphere absorbs signals in the LF and MF bands. At night, the D-layer disappears, allowing the sky wave to interfere with the surface wave. This interference occurs due to the different paths taken by the sky wave and surface wave, as well as the induction of currents in the horizontal elements of the loop aerial. The contamination effect, which is observed as fading of the audio signal and the needle 'hunting', is most pronounced around dawn and dusk when the ionosphere is transitioning. At shorter distances (30 to 80 miles), the sky waves combine with the ground wave signal without any dead space. Since the sky waves travel a different path, they have a different phase compared to the ground wave. As a result, the aerial null signal is suppressed or displaced in a random manner, leading to wandering of the needle on the RMI or RBI. This effect is called fading and is most variable during twilight at dawn and dusk.

content.question:
An aircraft is flying at an altitude of 8500 ft, and the distance received from a DME station situated at 596 ft elevation is 1.3 NM. What is the ground distance between the aircraft and the station?
(the DME range readout accuracy is 0.1 nm)

options.A: 0 nm
options.B: 1.5 nm
options.C: 1.3 nm
options.D: 1.8 nm

key_points: This is either a really bad question, or just quite sneaky, depending on how you look at it
The range readout to a DME is a slant range, and therefore we need to use Pythagoras' theorem to calculate the ground distance

Ground distance2 + height2 = slant distance2 Ground distance2 = slant distance2 - height2 Ground distance = sqrt(slant distance2 - height2) Therefore, if we take the question at face value, the slant range of 1
learning.explanation: This is either a really bad question, or just quite sneaky, depending on how you look at it. The range readout to a DME is a slant range, and therefore we need to use Pythagoras' theorem to calculate the ground distance. Ground distance2 + height2 = slant distance2 Ground distance2 = slant distance2 - height2 Ground distance = sqrt(slant distance2 - height2) Therefore, if we take the question at face value, the slant range of 1.3 nm is equal to 1.3 x 6080 = 7904 ft. The height of the aircraft above the DME is 8500 - 596 = 7904 ft. These numbers are the same so the ground distance is zero, and the aircraft is directly overhead the station. However, the DME range readout is only accurate to the nearest 0.1 nm (also stated in the question), so it is possible that the aircraft is actually at a slant range of up to 1.35 nm, and now we can perform the calculation properly. 1.35 x 6080 = 8208 ft. ground distance (ft) = sqrt(82062 - 79042) = 2206 ft ground distance (nm) = 2206/6080 = 0.36 nm, closest answer 0 nm.

content.question: What is the reason that a DME-station can generally respond to a maximum of 100 aircraft?

options.A: The minimum allowable accuracy of the range-measurement cannot be guaranteed when more than about 100 aircraft are using the same DME-station.
options.B: The number of reply pulse pairs per second that a DME-transponder can transmit is limited to a certain maximum value.
options.C: The automatic ground monitoring station of each DME-station has a limited capacity.
options.D: The memory of the DME-transponder is limited.

key_points: The response function of a DME transponder involves a continuous process that operates at a transmission rate of 2 700 pairs of pulses per second (ppps)
Once the transponder starts receiving pulses at this rate, it reaches a state of saturation, leading to an automatic reduction in its receiver gain
This adjustment has the consequence of filtering out transmissions from aircraft whose interrogation pulses are relatively weaker
learning.explanation: The response function of a DME transponder involves a continuous process that operates at a transmission rate of 2 700 pairs of pulses per second (ppps). Once the transponder starts receiving pulses at this rate, it reaches a state of saturation, leading to an automatic reduction in its receiver gain. This adjustment has the consequence of filtering out transmissions from aircraft whose interrogation pulses are relatively weaker. In practical terms, this translates to approximately 100 aircraft concurrently utilizing the DME system. The fortunate group of 100 consists of those aircraft emitting the most potent interrogation signals, rather than necessarily being the closest ones. When the ground-based DME station undergoes saturation, it exclusively acknowledges the 100 most robust signals.

content.question: A procedural VOR approach using a procedure turn is to be flown. The outbound leg follows the 098° radial from the VOR to a DME range of 6.0 NM, followed by a left turn onto a track of 018°(M), what should the next turn be?

options.A: A right turn onto a track of 278°(M) to intercept the inbound track.
options.B: A left turn onto a track of 233°(M) to intercept the inbound track.
options.C: A right turn onto a track of 233°(M) to intercept the inbound track.
options.D: A right turn onto a track of 198°(M) to intercept the inbound track.

key_points: In a procedural approach, often an aircraft will need to perform a reversal manoeuvre, in order to get from an outbound to an inbound track
There are many different ways this can be done, and the chosen method will be dictated clearly on the approach plate
Some of the available methods are the 45 180 procedure turn, the racetrack pattern, the teardrop procedure, and the 80 260 procedure turn
learning.explanation: In a procedural approach, often an aircraft will need to perform a reversal manoeuvre, in order to get from an outbound to an inbound track. There are many different ways this can be done, and the chosen method will be dictated clearly on the approach plate. Some of the available methods are the 45 180 procedure turn, the racetrack pattern, the teardrop procedure, and the 80 260 procedure turn. ICAO Doc 8168 3.2.2 Reversal procedure b) 80°/260° procedure turn ( starts at a facility or fix and consists of: 1) a straight leg with track guidance. This straight leg may be timed or may be limited by a radial or DME distance; 2) an 80° turn; 3) a 260° turn in the opposite direction to intercept the inbound track. The 80°/260° procedure turn is an alternative to the 45°/180° procedure turn [a) above] unless specifically excluded.

content.question: The magnetic variation to convert the RMI bearings of NDBs and VORs to true bearings will occur at the..

content.question: The ILS receiver of an aircraft on approach and flying to the right of the runway centreline will receive..

options.A: more of the 150 Hz localiser signal than the 90 Hz localiser signal.
options.B: the left lobe modulation only.
options.C: a modulated signal that will move the localiser needle to the right according to the magnitude of the difference between the two amplitudes.
options.D: the modulation from both lobes at equal amplitude.

key_points: As seen in the figure, the localizer as part of the ILS covers the lateral area in front of the runway
Which ever lobe the aircraft is closest to, will receive a greater strength
If the aircraft is to the left of the runway centre line, it will receive a greater strength from the 90 Hz lobe than from the 150 Hz lobe
learning.explanation: As seen in the figure, the localizer as part of the ILS covers the lateral area in front of the runway. Which ever lobe the aircraft is closest to, will receive a greater strength. If the aircraft is to the left of the runway centre line, it will receive a greater strength from the 90 Hz lobe than from the 150 Hz lobe. If the aircraft is to the right of the runway centreline line, it will receive a greater strength from the 150 Hz lobe than from the 90 Hz lobe. This is the principle of how the localizer works.

content.question: An aircraft at FL100 should be able to receive a VOR ground station at 100 ft above MSL at an approximate maximum range of..

options.A: 135 km
options.B: 135 NM
options.C: 125 NM
options.D: 220 NM

key_points: The VHF Omni-Range (VOR) station uses Very High Frequency (VHF) radiowaves to transfer in1formation
The formulae used to calculate the range of these radio waves is as follows: Maximum theoretical range (in nm) = 1
learning.explanation: The VHF Omni-Range (VOR) station uses Very High Frequency (VHF) radiowaves to transfer in1formation. The formulae used to calculate the range of these radio waves is as follows: Maximum theoretical range (in nm) = 1.23 x √H1 + 1.23 x √H2 H1 = the height in feet of the transmitter above mean sea level (MSL). H2 = the height in feet of the receiver above mean sea level (MSL). Knowing that: H1 = 10.000 ft H2 = 100 ft Filling in the formulae gives the following: Max range = 1.23 x √10.000 + 1.23 x √100 = 123 +12.3 = 135 nm

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft is flying on the 245° radial with a heading of 250° (M).The course is set to 060°. Which HSI shows the correct indications?

options.A: Figure B
options.B: Figure A
options.C: Figure C
options.D: Figure D

key_points: As seen in the figure the aircraft is on radial 245 from a station
A radial is always from a station
When the (green) course 060 is selected also the (red) reciprocal (060 + 180 = 240) can be drawn since the aircraft is on the opposite side of the selected course
learning.explanation: As seen in the figure the aircraft is on radial 245 from a station. A radial is always from a station. When the (green) course 060 is selected also the (red) reciprocal (060 + 180 = 240) can be drawn since the aircraft is on the opposite side of the selected course. Regarding the aircraft heading, the aircraft is going roughly in the same direction as the radial. The selected (red) course will be indicated on the HSI and will show a deflection to the left. Remember, the deflection needle tells where the aircraft is relative to the selected course. Because the aircraft is on a radial and the selected course is on the other side of the station, this will indicate a ‘to’ indication. If course 240 is selected then it would be a ‘from’ indication. Therefore figure A is the correct answer.

content.question: After tuning the correct ILS frequency, and receiving the correct ident, the pilot notice that the Localiser (LOC) and Glide Path (GP) indicators are both showing warning flags. The pilot confirms that the aircraft is within the prescribed coverage area of the ILS. What is the most probable reason for the warning flags showing?

options.A: An incorrect course is selected on the OBI or HSI.
options.B: More than full scale deflections are indicated.
options.C: The aircraft receives modulating frequencies of 90 and 150 Hz at a rate of 0%.
options.D: Another aircraft ahead, on the same ILS approach, is disturbing the transmission.

key_points: Learning Objective 062
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 062.02.05.02.05: Describe the circumstances in which warning flags will appear for both the LOC and the GP: absence of the carrier frequency; absence of the modulation simultaneously; the percentage modulation of the navigation signal reduced to 0. When within the coverage area of the ILS, and receiving the ident, that means that the carrier wave for the correct LOC is definitely being received, but showing flags for both LOC and GS is not what you would expect in normal operation. When flags are shown, it is due to any of the items listed in the LO above, or possibly due to the received signal being below a certain strength. This narrows down the possible failures to a modulation problem. Also, the other possible answers are wrong as: selected course does not affect ILS signals or indication. Any more than full scale deflection (within the coverage area) shows exactly that, full scale deflection. An aircraft ahead of yours might cause a momentary change in the ILS indication due to signal reflection, but this woud be a tiny blip indeed.

An aircraft is flying at a specific height and a specific lateral distance from the DME station
The aircraft sends out a radio signal to the DME station and uses the time it takes to travel to calculate the slant distance from the aircraft to the DME station

content.question: In the VOR receiver, the radial is determined by measuring the..

options.A: doppler shift of the reference signal.
options.B: time difference between the reception of the variable signal and the reference signal.
options.C: phase difference between the variable signal and the reference signal.
options.D: phase of the variable signal.

key_points: A VOR ground station sends a highly directional signal, by making use of a so called phased array antenna
Together with this signal, the VOR sends a 30 Hz reference signal which is equal in all direction
The phase difference between the reference signal and the highly directional signal, is the bearing from the VOR station relative to Magnetic North
learning.explanation: A VOR ground station sends a highly directional signal, by making use of a so called phased array antenna. Together with this signal, the VOR sends a 30 Hz reference signal which is equal in all direction. The phase difference between the reference signal and the highly directional signal, is the bearing from the VOR station relative to Magnetic North. A VOR receiver works by comparing the phase relationship between a reference signal and a variable signal.

content.question: The BFO selector switch on the ADF control panel must be in the "ON" position to enable the pilot to:

options.A: Hear the IDENT of NDBs using N0N A1A transmissions.
options.B: Adjust the loop to the aural null position.
options.C: Stop the loop rotation.
options.D: Hear the IDENT of NDBs using N0N A2A transmissions.

key_points: Navigational NDBs have an unmodulated carrier wave (ICAO classification N0N)
Station identification is transmitted at roughly ten second intervals
Older systems interrupt the carrier wave (Keying) to send an unmodulated (but also inaudible) morse code ident (classified as A1A)
learning.explanation: Navigational NDBs have an unmodulated carrier wave (ICAO classification N0N). Station identification is transmitted at roughly ten second intervals. Older systems interrupt the carrier wave (Keying) to send an unmodulated (but also inaudible) morse code ident (classified as A1A). User will have also erratic indications while the signal is interrupted in this type of beacon. To make the unmodulated parts of the A1A signal audible, ADF equipment incorporates a Beat Frequency Oscillator (BF0) that produces a signal slightly removed from the received frequency that is then mixed with it. The mixing of the two frequencies produces an audible beat frequency, tahat is the difference of the two. Summary: selecting the BFO on makes the N0N carrier wave audible and allows the A1A type of ident to be heard. Note: BFO is not needed for an A2A signal which is already modulated to an audible frequency.
